channel.description: Recent content in Songwriting on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Welcome to this guide on songwriting! As always, I’ll be efficient and don’t waste your time. Yes, there are ten chapters, but each is quite short and has many examples.

item.title: What do I need?
item.description: Technically, all you need for songwriting is something to write down the song. Pen on paper works. Typing on a laptop as well.

item.title: Where do I start?
item.description: The short answer is: anywhere you like. Especially with something as broad and emotional as music, any starting point is fine.

item.title: Repetition & Surprise
item.description: This article explains a principle that is crucial to any creative field, and songwriting is no exception. In fact, it’s even more important and it’s even easier to see it in action.

item.title: Rhythm I
item.description: I know what you’re thinking. Rhythm? Really? That’s where you want to start? Yes, no doubt about it. We’re all so focused on pitches, but rhythm is actually king.

item.title: Rhythm II
item.description: As promised, this chapter focuses on specific tips you can immediately apply to your songwriting. They will prove true for any part (also pitches and lyrics).

item.title: Melody I
item.description: The word melody technically refers to both pitch and rhythm. These chapters were, therefore, called “pitch” at first. But that seemed like a weird title—one that many people wouldn’t find when searching for it.

item.title: Melody II
item.description: As promised, this chapter gives all my practical tips about writing melody. But first, we discuss the one truth that explains all of them.

item.title: Rules & Patterns
item.description: I wanted to explain this earlier. If you remember one thing from this guide, make it this thing. So why didn’t I do it?

item.title: Lyrics I
item.description: Lyrics mostly follow the same principles as Rhythm and Pitch. I mean, I’ve explained the importance of rhyming ten times—and that’s a concept most people will only know from language!

item.title: Lyrics II
item.description: Last chapter talked about putting lyrics to a melody you already have. Now we start with lyrics and try to put a melody to that.

item.title: Arrangement I
item.description: So far, we focused on one instrument or singer. One melodic line. To finish this guide, we need to take the obvious last step: how to combine multiple great melodies?

item.title: Arrangement II
item.description: In this last chapter, I’ll give specific practical tips for designing another melody against an existing melody. This concept is usually called counterpoint: the relationship between two melodies played at the same time.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: There you have it! All my tips and practical philosophy on composing and songwriting. You have learned …
